1.text: Whither is thy beloved gone, O thou fairest among women? Whither hath thy beloved turned him, That we may seek him with thee?

2.text: My beloved is gone down to his garden, To the beds of spices, To feed in the gardens, and to gather lilies.

3.text: I am my belovedâ€™s, and my beloved is mine: He feedeth his flock among the lilies.

4.text: Thou art fair, O my love, as Tirzah, Comely as Jerusalem, Terrible as an army with banners.

5.text: Turn away thine eyes from me, For they have overcome me. Thy hair is as a flock of goats, That lie along the side of Gilead.

6.text: Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes, Which are come up from the washing; Whereof every one hath twins, And none is bereaved among them.

7.text: Thy temples are like a piece of a pomegranate Behind thy veil.

8.text: There are threescore queens, and fourscore concubines, And virgins without number.

9.text: My dove, my undefiled, is but one; She is the only one of her mother; She is the choice one of her that bare her. The daughters saw her, and called her blessed; Yea, the queens and the concubines, and they praised her.

10.text: Who is she that looketh forth as the morning, Fair as the moon, Clear as the sun, Terrible as an army with banners?

11.text: I went down into the garden of nuts, To see the green plants of the valley, To see whether the vine budded, And the pomegranates were in flower.

12.text: Before I was aware, my soul set me Among the chariots of my princely people.

13.text: Return, return, O Shulammite; Return, return, that we may look upon thee. Why will ye look upon the Shulammite, As upon the dance of Mahanaim?
